items.title: STING induces ZBP1-mediated necroptosis independently of TNFR1 and FADD
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09536-4 STING induces ZBP1-mediated necroptosis independently of TNFR1 and FADD

items.title: Water in the Devils Comet shares a source with Earths oceans
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02588-6 Chemical profiling traces the source of water in one of the brightest known comets to keep returning to the Solar System.

items.title: The worlds largest methane emitter manages to curb one source
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02629-0 Output of the powerful greenhouse gas by Chinas energy sector peaked in 2014, an inventory shows.

items.title: Fusion energy gets a boost from cold fusion chemistry
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02683-8 Chemists used an electrochemical method to enhance the rates of fusion in a desktop reactor  plus, how microbes give chocolate its taste.

items.title: When will dengue strike? Outbreaks sync with heat and rain
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02677-6 Analysis uncovers seasonal patterns of the mosquito-borne disease across the Americas, which could anticipate future outbreaks.

items.title: Structural basis for the dynamic regulation of mTORC1 by amino acids
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09428-7 Using cryo-electron microscopy, the interactions of Sestrin2 and CASTOR1 with GATOR2 were resolved, revealing how mTORC1 activation is regulated and how nutrient availability triggers signalling for cellular growth.

items.title: mAChR4 suppresses liver disease via GAP-induced antimicrobial immunity
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09395-z Chronic alcohol use in humans and mice downregulates small intestinal mAChR4 and reduces goblet-cell-associated antigen passage formation, disrupting antimicrobial immunity.

items.title: Molecular mechanism of ultrafast transport by plasma membrane Ca<sup>2+</sup>-ATPases
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09402-3 Structural insights into ultrafast Ca2+ transport by plasma membrane Ca2+-ATPases are provided, highlighting an essential role for PtdIns(4,5)P2 dynamics.

items.title: Proximity screening greatly enhances electronic quality of graphene
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09386-0 Screening by a graphite gate placed at 1 nm proximity to graphene produces transformative improvement in its electronic quality, reducing charge inhomogeneity by two orders of magnitude.

items.title: TCF1 and LEF1 promote B-1a cell homeostasis and regulatory function
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09421-0 The transcription factors TCF1 and LEF1 promote self-renewal and regulatory functions in B-1a cells.

items.title: Experimental determination of partial charges with electron diffraction
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09405-0 An experimental method is used to assign partial charges based on crystal structure determination through electron diffraction, applicable to any crystalline compound.

items.title: Targeting G1S-checkpoint-compromised cancers with cyclin A/B RxL inhibitors
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09433-w Dual cyclin A/B RxL inhibitors selectively kill small cell lung cancer cells and other cancer cells with high E2F activity.

items.title: Realization of a doped quantum antiferromagnet in a Rydberg tweezer array
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09377-1 A doped quantum antiferromagnet is obtained by using a Rydberg tweezer array comprising three levels encoding spins and holes to implement a tunable model that allows the study of previously inaccessible parameter regimes.

items.title: Electron flow matching for generative reaction mechanism prediction
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09426-9 A new tool based on generative machine learning called FlowER uses flow matching to model reactions as the redistribution of electrons between reactants and products, enabling the enforcement of mass conservation in reaction prediction.

items.title: A fluorescent-protein spin qubit
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09417-w An optically addressable fluorescent-protein spin qubit is realized using enhanced yellow fluorescent protein; the qubit can be coherently controlled at liquid-nitrogen temperatures and the spin detected at room temperature in cells.

items.title: Electrochemical loading enhances deuterium fusion rates in a metal target
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09042-7 A benchtop fusion reactor, called the Thunderbird Reactor, is described, showing that electrochemically loading a metal lattice with deuterium could enhance nuclear fusion rates when that metal is also bombarded by deuterium ions.

items.title: Thymic epithelial cells amplify epigenetic noise to promote immune tolerance
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09424-x The activity of the tumour-suppressor protein p53 is repressed in the thymus to augment fluctuations in background chromatin accessibility as a means of mediating ectopic gene expression and immune tolerance.

items.title: Emerging evidence of abrupt changes in the Antarctic environment
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09349-5 Abrupt changes are developing across Antarcticas ice, ocean and biological systems; some of these changes are intensifying faster than equivalent Arctic changes, potentially irreversibly, and their interactions are expected to worsen other impacts across the Antarctic environment and global climate system.

items.title: Engineered yeast provides rare but essential pollen sterols for honeybees
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09431-y Genetic engineering of a yeast strain provides rare but essential pollen sterols for honeybee colonies.

items.title: Extremely stripped supernova reveals a silicon and sulfur formation site
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09375-3 Observations of SN 2021yfj reveal that its progenitor is a massive star stripped down to its O/Si/S core, which remarkably continued to expel vast quantities of silicon-, sulfur-, and argon-rich material before the explosion, informing us that current theories for how stars evolve are too narrow.

items.title: Atomic dynamics of gas-dependent oxide reducibility
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09394-0 Environmental transmission electron microscopy reveals distinct atomistic pathways for the reduction of NiO to metallic nickel by CO and H2, with H2 more effective in transforming the entire bulk material.

items.title: Cancer-induced nerve injury promotes resistance to anti-PD-1 therapy
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09370-8 Perineural invasion and cancer-induced nerve injury of tumour-associated nerves are associated with poor response to anti-PD-1 therapy, which can be reversed by combining anti-PD-1 therapy with anti-inflammatory interventions.

items.title: A novel bacterial protein family that catalyses nitrous oxide reduction
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09401-4 Cultivation of tropical soil microorganisms combined with physiological experiments and bioinformatics analyses identify a family of clade III lactonase-type nitrous oxide reductases with low sequence identity but high 3D structural similarity to known nitrous oxide reductases.

items.title: SLC45A4 is a pain gene encoding a neuronal polyamine transporter
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09326-y The SLC45A4 gene encodes a neuronal polyamine transporter and is linked to pain response in humans and mice.

items.title: A missing enzyme-rescue metabolite as cause of a rare skeletal dysplasia
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09397-x In mammals, the enzyme TGDS produces UDP-4-keto-6-deoxyglucose, which binds to the catalytic pocket of UDP-xylose synthase, thereby regenerating the essential NAD+ cofactor of UDP-xylose synthase in conditions of low NAD+.

items.title: Quantitative imaging of lipid transport in mammalian cells
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09432-x Directional, non-vesicular lipid transport is responsible for fast, species-selective lipid sorting into organelle membranes.

items.title: Discovery of a widespread chemical signalling pathway in the Bacteroidota
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09418-9 The N-acyl-cyclolysine system regulates the expression of co-localized operons encoding diverse secreted molecules in Bacteroidota.

items.title: Flat-panel laser displays through large-scale photonic integrated circuits
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09107-7 Photonic integrated circuits allow laser displays to be flattened into a compact form factor while improving efficiency and colour performance.

items.title: Network synchrony creates neural filters promoting quiescence in Drosophila
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09376-2 In Drosophila, coherent slow-wave activity between sleep-promoting and locomotion-promoting neural networks provides a brain state structure that allows for quiescent behaviours.

items.title: Axonal injury is a targetable driver of glioblastoma progression
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41586-025-09411-2 Axonal injury, induced in the white matter by expansion of early tumour cells, is a key driver of glioblastoma progression.

items.title: Could these five future agricultural innovations slow down climate change?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02321-3 From AI-powered bee monitors to genetically modified yeasts that make protein, here are some solutions that are set to revolutionize the future of food.

items.title: Dying star reveals its inner structure
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02425-w A star that was stripped of its outer layers shortly before it exploded as a supernova offers astronomers an unprecedented glimpse of a stellar interior.

items.title: What counts as plagiarism? AI-generated papers pose new risks
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02616-5 Researchers argue over whether novel AI-generated works use others ideas without credit.

items.title: Before making a career move, try an experiment
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02437-6 How to use a curiosity-led strategy to find the right role.

items.title: Securing climate justice in the courtroom
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02623-6 Advances in climate modelling are clarifying accountability for global warming.

items.title: Rare skeletal condition caused by enzymes failure to rescue a catalytic cycle
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02428-7 When enzymes require rescue strategies to complete progression through their reaction, but natural safety nets fail, disease states can ensue.

items.title: Pay gap between nationals and migrants mainly due to unequal access to high-paying jobs
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02546-2 In high-income nations, immigrants earn substantially less than do people born in those countries, mainly because of a lack of access to high-paying jobs. Addressing this economic disparity will require policy efforts that expand access to better-paying occupations and firms rather than just enforcing policies of equal pay for equal work.

items.title: How citizen science can help to solve the global freshwater crisis
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02614-7 Encouraging people to test their local rivers and lakes with simple kits could spark a shift in how we manage water.

items.title: A double-whammy problem: how plastic dust is altering natural processes
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02438-5 Carbon emissions from plastics production are no surprise. But when plastic turns to dust, it also affects how the planet absorbs carbon from the air, on land and in the oceans.

items.title: Low-energy nuclear fusion boosted by electrochemistry
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02254-x Electrochemistry can boost processes that trap atoms inside a metal. A reactor uses these trapped atoms, combined with an ion beam, as fuel for nuclear fusion.

items.title: Feeding bees with engineered yeast combats colony decline
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02600-z Nutritionally complete food for honeybees (Apis mellifera) has been generated by engineering yeast to produce rare but essential sterol molecules found in pollen. Honeybee colonies fed with the yeast-supplemented diet produced offspring for longer periods than did those fed sterol-deficient diets. This approach makes it possible to rear honeybees without pollen.

items.title: Visualizing lipid transport in cells
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02603-w Lipid molecules form the membranes that organize cellular biochemistry in all domains of life. Imaging approaches have been developed to visualize different types of lipid at subcellular scales and show that these molecules are sorted into membranes by lipid transfer proteins, rather than by vesicles.

items.title: Anticancer compounds that exploit a compromised checkpoint in the cell cycle
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02606-7 Many cancer-driving mutations disable a key checkpoint in the cells cycle between growth and division, resulting in unchecked activity of the E2F family of transcription factor proteins. A set of compounds developed to directly block key regulators of the cell cycle called cyclins can suppress the growth of cancers driven by high E2F activity.

items.title: Times arrow
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02625-4 Know your place.

items.title: Evasive condensate caught by fingerprints
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-03017-1 Like charges can pair up to make superconductors, so intuitively opposite charges should also have no trouble forming pairs. But condensates of electronhole pairs are not common  one must search carefully for their fingerprints.

items.title: Optical signatures of interlayer electron coherence in a bilayer semiconductor
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-02971-0 Condensates of excitons have been observed in the quantum Hall regime, but evidence for their existence at low magnetic fields remains controversial. Now evidence of coherence between optically pumped interlayer excitons in MoS2 marks a step towards confirming exciton condensation at low magnetic fields.

items.title: Carbon subsurface traffic jam as driver for methane oxidation activity and selectivity on palladium surfaces
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63088-9 Separating how sub- and surface species affect catalyst function is a challenge. Here, the authors follow sub- and surface carbon time-resolved in a Pd catalyst while oxidizing CH4 and show that subsurface carbon traffic jam changes the catalyst function.

items.title: A lithography-free approach to polaritonic Luneburg lenses
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63097-8 This study presents a lithography-free and cost-effective strategy for fabricating planar polaritonic Luneburg lenses, based on the controlled melting of polymer microspheres on the surface of van der Waals polaritonic materials.

items.title: Non-genetic neuromodulation with graphene optoelectronic actuators for disease models, stem cell maturation, and biohybrid robotics
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62637-6 Light can control neural activity but often requires genetic modification. Here, the authors present a graphene-based platform for non-genetic light controlled neuronal stimulation, enabling all-optical network analysis, stem cell derived neuron maturation, and closed-loop robotics.

items.title: Nanopore sequencing of intact aminoacylated tRNAs
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62545-9 Accurate protein synthesis depends on aminoacylated tRNAs, but their identities have been hard to measure. Here, authors present aa-tRNA-seq, a nanopore-based method that reveals the amino acid, sequence, and modification status of individual tRNAs at single-molecule resolution.

items.title: Disordered-guiding photonic chip enabled high-dimensional light field detection
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-63130-w The authors present an on-chip intelligent high-dimensional light field detection system for single-shot accurate measurement of intensity, polarization, and spectrum  achieving superior resolution and integration compared to conventional system

items.title: Cryo-EM structure of ribosome from pathogenic protozoa Entamoeba histolytica reveals unique features of its architecture
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62767-x Entamoeba histolytica causes bloody diarrhea and liver abscesses in humans. Here, the authors report the cryo-EM structure of E. histolytica ribosomes from its disease-causing, trophozoite state and reveal several unique features, such as the rRNA triple helix motif.

items.title: In-cell structure and variability of pyrenoid Rubisco
items.summary: Nature Communications, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41467-025-62998-y Rubisco is a central enzyme in the global CO2 fixation during photosynthesis. Using cryo-ET on cryo-FIB milled alga cells, the authors reveal the native structures, interactions, and spatial organization of Rubisco within the pyrenoid of green algae.

items.title: Enhancing spectroscopy and microscopy with emerging methods in photon correlation and quantum illumination
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 20 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-01992-3 This Review discusses single-photon detectors and quantum-light sources for super-resolution microscopy, measurements below classical noise limits and photon-number-resolved spectroscopy as emerging tools for nanoscale electronic materials characterization and bioimaging.

items.title: Finding your academic voice: faster, healthier writing with AI speech recognition
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02418-9 Voice-to-text tools powered by artificial intelligence can make life easier for academics by replacing the keyboard with dictation and transcription.

items.title: A baby benefits from personalized gene editing in the clinic
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02590-y An infant with an inherited life-threatening metabolic condition has responded to a tailored therapy that uses the gene-editing tool CRISPR to correct a specific mutation.

items.title: Battery prices are falling, so why are electric cars still so expensive?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02619-2 Policies incentivizing electrified transport dont seem to be working. Heres what we need to do.

items.title: Small, affordable undergraduate research programmes changed my career and strengthen US science. Why cut them?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02242-1 Like so much else, this small scientific programme is on the Trump administrations hit list. This will hurt the United States, says Dan Seaton.

items.title: Exercise improves survival of some people with colon cancer, clinical trial shows
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02591-x Most studies on how exercise affects the survival of people with cancer have been observational. A clinical trial provides compelling evidence of the benefits of physical activity.

items.title: People are having fewer babies: Is it really the end of the world?
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02615-6 Steep population declines in most countries are expected to have negative impacts over the next several generations, but adaptation is possible.

items.title: Why strong mentorship was essential for my career success in science
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02634-3 JoAnn Trejo has turned mentoring into an evidence-based science, driven by her own exposure to inspiring mentors.

items.title: Immunotherapy using CAR T cells shows promising long-term outcomes for people with the blood cancer myeloma
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02592-w A clinical trial reports data from one of the first groups of people with the blood cancer myeloma to receive a type of immunotherapy called CAR T cells.

items.title: How changes in behaviour can save lives in disasters
items.summary: Nature, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-02613-8 Enabling people to take more personal responsibility for their safety can reduce the risks posed by earthquakes and floods.

items.title: Magnon-polaritons dance around exceptional points
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-02999-2 Coherent control of magnon excitations is crucial for their potential device application. The integration of the exceptional point in a magnon-photon hybrid system is shown to offer fast, coherent and topologically robust control of magnon-polariton states.

items.title: Coherent control of magnonpolaritons using an exceptional point
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-02998-3 Deterministic control of the gainloss balance in non-Hermitian systems remains challenging. A magnonic hybrid platform is now shown to enable this and, hence, coherently control excitations by leveraging an exceptional point.

items.title: Image-guided treatment of mouse tumours with radioactive ion beams
items.summary: Nature Physics, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41567-025-02993-8 Particle therapy is subject to uncertainties in the range of the beam. In this study, tumours in the necks of mice were treated with radioactive ion beams, which enabled real-time verification of the beam range.

items.title: Orchestrated growth factor release for muscle restoration
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02330-7 Implantable bioconstructs with sequential release of growth factors promote enhanced myofibre formation, angiogenesis and innervation in a mouse model of volumetric muscle loss.

items.title: Signatures of magnetism in zigzag graphene nanoribbons embedded in a hexagonal boron nitride lattice
items.summary: Nature Materials, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41563-025-02317-4 Nitrogen-vacancy-centre microscopy and anisotropic magnetoresistance measurements reveal the evidence of magnetism in zigzag graphene nanoribbons embedded in hexagonal boron nitride.

items.title: An energy metabolism-engaged nanomedicine maintains mitochondrial homeostasis to alleviate cellular ageing
items.summary: Nature Nanotechnology, Published online: 19 August 2025; doi:10.1038/s41565-025-01972-7 Through binding mitochondrial ATP synthase, engineered nanomedicines rejuvenate aged bone stem cells and restore osteogenesis, reversing osteoporosis in mice and offering a potential senolytic therapy for skeletal ageing.
